title: Ezekiel Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 2.

questions.question: Who is told to stand upon his feet in Ezekiel 2?
questions.correctAnswer: Son of man
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:1 states, 'Son of man, stand upon thy feet, and I will speak unto thee.'

questions.question: What entered into Ezekiel when he was spoken to?
questions.correctAnswer: The spirit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:2 says, 'And the spirit entered into me when he spake unto me.'

questions.question: To whom is Ezekiel sent according to Ezekiel 2?
questions.correctAnswer: Children of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:3 states, 'I send thee to the children of Israel.'

questions.question: How does Ezekiel describe the nation he is sent to?
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellious nation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:3 calls the children of Israel a 'rebellious nation.'

questions.question: What kind of children are described in Ezekiel 2:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Impudent and stiffhearted
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:4 describes them as 'impudent children and stiffhearted.'

questions.question: What will the people know even if they don't listen to Ezekiel?
options: There hath been a prophet among them
questions.correctAnswer: There hath been a prophet among them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:5 says they 'shall know that there hath been a prophet among them.'

questions.question: What is Ezekiel told not to be afraid of?
questions.correctAnswer: Their words and looks
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:6 instructs him not to fear their words or be dismayed at their looks.

questions.question: What creatures does Ezekiel dwell among according to Ezekiel 2?
questions.correctAnswer: Scorpions
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:6 mentions that he dwells among scorpions.

questions.question: What is Ezekiel commanded to do with God's words?
questions.correctAnswer: Speak them to the people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:7 commands him to speak God's words whether they hear or forbear.

questions.question: Ezekiel is told to open his mouth and eat what is given to him. What is this an instruction against?
questions.correctAnswer: Being rebellious
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:8 tells him not to be rebellious like the rebellious house.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel see in the hand that is sent to him?
questions.correctAnswer: A roll of a book
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:9 describes an hand sent to him holding a roll of a book.

questions.question: True or False: The book Ezekiel saw was written only on the outside.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:10 states the book was written within and without.

questions.question: True or False: The book Ezekiel saw contained words of lamentations, mourning, and woe.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:10 says the book had written therein lamentations, mourning, and woe.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel was told to be afraid of the rebellious house.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:6 instructs him not to be afraid of them or their words.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezekiel 2:1: 'Son of man, stand upon thy ______, and I will speak unto thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: feet
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:1 says, 'Son of man, stand upon thy feet, and I will speak unto thee.'

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling fearful about speaking God's truth to a difficult community. Based on Ezekiel 2, what biblical truth would you share about overcoming fear?
options: Be not afraid of their words or looks, even if they are rebellious
Avoid speaking if people might reject you
Only speak when you feel completely confident
Wait for others to speak first before sharing God's word
questions.correctAnswer: Be not afraid of their words or looks, even if they are rebellious
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:6 encourages not being afraid of the words or looks of a rebellious people, reinforcing faith and courage in obedience. This is supported by verses 2:6, 2:7, and 2:4 which emphasize boldness in proclaiming God's message.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 2 teach us about obedience to God's calling even when the people are rebellious?
options: Speak God’s words whether they hear or refuse
Choose to speak only to those who listen
Stop speaking if people are disobedient
Seek approval before delivering God’s message
questions.correctAnswer: Speak God’s words whether they hear or refuse
questions.explanation: Verses 2:5 and 2:7 instruct to speak God's words regardless of the people's response, emphasizing obedience over results. This model teaches perseverance in faith and witness despite rejection.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 2 suggest about responding to spiritual rebellion in family and community?
options: Do not be rebellious yourself and submit to God’s word
Only engage with those who are obedient
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be rebellious yourself and submit to God’s word
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:8 warns the 'son of man' not to be rebellious like the rebellious house but to open his mouth and eat what God gives, symbolizing submission and obedience. This teaches humility and faithfulness in difficult environments.

questions.question: In a situation where a believer is discouraged because their efforts to share the Gospel are met with rejection, what encouragement does Ezekiel 2 give?
options: They will know a prophet has been among them, regardless of acceptance
Only share with those who invite you
Change your message to please others
questions.correctAnswer: They will know a prophet has been among them, regardless of acceptance
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:5 states that whether the people hear or forbear, they will know a prophet was among them, affirming the importance of faithful witness regardless of response.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline is symbolized by the instruction to 'open thy mouth, and eat that I give thee' in Ezekiel 2?
options: Receiving and internalizing God's word faithfully
Sharing only pleasant messages with others
questions.correctAnswer: Receiving and internalizing God's word faithfully
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:8 uses the metaphor of eating the scroll to describe accepting and internalizing God’s word, a key spiritual discipline for obedience and growth.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 2 illustrate the reality of spiritual opposition in ministry?
options: Describes dwelling among scorpions, briers, and thorns
Says ministry will be easy and pleasant
Promises no opposition for God's servants
questions.correctAnswer: Describes dwelling among scorpions, briers, and thorns
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:6 metaphorically describes opposition as living among scorpions and thorns, teaching believers to persevere through trials in ministry.

questions.question: What attitude toward rebellious people does Ezekiel 2 teach for those sharing God’s word?
options: Speak God’s words faithfully without fear or discouragement
Change your message to be more acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: Speak God’s words faithfully without fear or discouragement
questions.explanation: Verses 2:4, 2:6, and 2:7 instruct speaking God’s words without fear or discouragement, even to a rebellious house, emphasizing faithfulness and love in witness.

questions.question: A believer struggles with discouragement because their family has rebelled against God for generations. What biblical truth from Ezekiel 2 offers hope?
options: God still sends prophets to rebellious generations to call them to repentance
You must reject your family to be faithful
God only works with obedient families
questions.correctAnswer: God still sends prophets to rebellious generations to call them to repentance
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:3 acknowledges a rebellious nation and their fathers but also shows God’s ongoing sending of prophets, highlighting God’s faithfulness and calling despite long-term rebellion.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 2 guide believers in dealing with the temptation to become rebellious themselves when facing opposition?
options: Be not rebellious like the rebellious house but obey God’s word
Join in rebellion to fit in
Ignore God's word when it's hard
Give up ministry if opposition arises
questions.correctAnswer: Be not rebellious like the rebellious house but obey God’s word
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:8 warns against becoming rebellious like those to whom the message is sent, emphasizing perseverance and obedience even in adversity.

questions.question: What does the scroll in Ezekiel 2 symbolize in the life of a believer?
options: The word of God containing lamentations, mourning, and woe to be received and proclaimed
A secret code to be hidden
questions.correctAnswer: The word of God containing lamentations, mourning, and woe to be received and proclaimed
questions.explanation: Verses 2:9-10 describe a scroll written inside and outside with lamentations, mourning, and woe, symbolizing the difficult truths of God’s word that must be accepted and shared.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 2 teaches that it is acceptable to be fearful and hesitant when speaking God's message to others.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:6 commands not to be afraid of the words or looks of the rebellious, emphasizing courage and boldness rather than fear.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 2 indicates that God’s message should only be shared with those who are willing to listen.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 2:5 and 2:7 make clear that God’s words are to be spoken whether the people hear or forbear, showing obedience to God’s command over human response.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Ezekiel 2:4, the children of Israel are described as ______ and stiffhearted.
questions.correctAnswer: impudent
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:4 calls the children of Israel 'impudent children and stiffhearted,' highlighting their rebellious nature which the prophet must confront.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 2 teach about perseverance through trials in Christian service?
options: Endure despite opposition, dwelling among scorpions and thorns
Only serve when circumstances are easy
Avoid any form of trial or opposition
questions.correctAnswer: Endure despite opposition, dwelling among scorpions and thorns
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:6 uses imagery of dwelling among scorpions and thorns to represent trials in ministry, teaching perseverance and trust in God.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 2, what should be the believer’s response to God’s instructions even if the message contains lamentations and woe?
options: Accept and proclaim the message faithfully
Reject the message because it is discouraging
Delay sharing until the message changes
questions.correctAnswer: Accept and proclaim the message faithfully
questions.explanation: Verses 2:9-10 describe the scroll with lamentations and woe which Ezekiel is instructed to eat, symbolizing acceptance and proclamation of all God’s word, even difficult parts.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 2.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'Son of man' as used in Ezekiel 2:1 when God addresses Ezekiel?
options: It emphasizes Ezekiel's humanity in contrast to God's divinity
It is a title of priestly authority
It refers to Ezekiel's prophetic dreams
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes Ezekiel's humanity in contrast to God's divinity
questions.explanation: The phrase 'Son of man' highlights Ezekiel's human status, distinguishing him from God, consistent with its use in Ezekiel 2:1 where God calls him to stand and listen.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 2:2, what does the spirit entering Ezekiel symbolize, especially in the context of prophetic commissioning in the Hebrew Bible?
options: Empowerment by God's presence to fulfill his prophetic mission
A physical possession by an angel
questions.correctAnswer: Empowerment by God's presence to fulfill his prophetic mission
questions.explanation: The spirit entering Ezekiel represents divine empowerment, a common theme in prophetic calls, enabling him to stand and hear God's message as stated in Ezekiel 2:2.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 2:3, whom is Ezekiel sent to, and what is the characterization of this group?
options: The children of Israel, described as a rebellious nation
The Philistines, as enemies of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The children of Israel, described as a rebellious nation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:3 explicitly states that Ezekiel is sent to the children of Israel, described as a rebellious nation that has transgressed against God.

questions.question: What literary device is used in Ezekiel 2:4 with the terms 'impudent children' and 'stiffhearted,' and what does it convey?
options: Metaphor to depict stubbornness and rebellion
Simile to compare Israel to wild animals
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor to depict stubbornness and rebellion
questions.explanation: The terms are metaphoric descriptions illustrating Israel’s obstinacy and rebellion against God, as presented in Ezekiel 2:4.

questions.question: Ezekiel 2:5 mentions that the people will know 'that there hath been a prophet among them' regardless of their response. What does this imply about the role of prophecy?
options: Prophecy serves as a witness to divine truth, independent of acceptance
Prophecy is meant to be comforting and always accepted
Prophecy is conditional on the people's obedience
Prophecy is primarily for private revelation
questions.correctAnswer: Prophecy serves as a witness to divine truth, independent of acceptance
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:5 states that whether the people hear or not, they will recognize the presence of a prophet, indicating prophecy's role as a witness regardless of response.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 2:6, what is the significance of the imagery 'though briers and thorns be with thee, and thou dost dwell among scorpions'?
options: It symbolizes the hostility and danger Ezekiel will face among the rebellious people
It represents the agricultural challenges of the land
It is a metaphor for spiritual purity
It refers to the protection God provides from wild animals
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the hostility and danger Ezekiel will face among the rebellious people
questions.explanation: The imagery in Ezekiel 2:6 metaphorically portrays the difficult and hostile environment Ezekiel will encounter as a prophet.

questions.question: Ezekiel 2:7 repeats the instruction to speak God's words regardless of the people’s response. How does this reinforce the theme of prophetic obedience?
options: It emphasizes unwavering commitment to deliver God's message
It suggests flexibility in the message depending on audience
It encourages silence if the message is rejected
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes unwavering commitment to deliver God's message
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:7 underscores the prophet's duty to speak God's words without fear or hesitation, regardless of acceptance.

questions.question: What is the significance of the command in Ezekiel 2:8 to 'open thy mouth, and eat that I give thee' in prophetic tradition?
options: It symbolizes internalizing God's word to faithfully proclaim it
It is a literal instruction for sustenance
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes internalizing God's word to faithfully proclaim it
questions.explanation: The eating of the scroll in Ezekiel 2:8 is a metaphor for assimilating God's message, a common prophetic motif indicating readiness to proclaim God's word.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 2:9-10, the scroll is described as being written within and without with lamentations, mourning, and woe. What does this dual inscription likely signify?
options: The comprehensive and unavoidable nature of impending judgment
The dual authorship of the scroll
questions.correctAnswer: The comprehensive and unavoidable nature of impending judgment
questions.explanation: The writing on both sides of the scroll with lamentations and woe in Ezekiel 2:9-10 symbolizes the all-encompassing judgment that cannot be ignored.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 2:3's description of Israel as a 'rebellious nation' connect with the theme of covenant disobedience found elsewhere in the Hebrew Bible?
options: It echoes Deuteronomy's warnings about covenant breach and consequences
It refers to a new covenant not previously mentioned
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes Deuteronomy's warnings about covenant breach and consequences
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:3's characterization of Israel as rebellious aligns with Deuteronomy's emphasis on covenant unfaithfulness and divine judgment.

questions.question: What role does the concept of 'not being afraid' in Ezekiel 2:6 play in the broader prophetic narrative and its challenges?
options: It encourages prophetic courage amidst opposition and rejection
It discourages engagement with the people
It mandates silence in perilous times
questions.correctAnswer: It encourages prophetic courage amidst opposition and rejection
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:6 instructs the prophet to remain fearless despite threats, a recurring theme in prophetic calls to boldness.

questions.question: Which Old Testament book similarly uses the motif of a prophet eating a scroll to symbolize receiving God's message?
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:16 also describes the prophet eating a scroll as a symbol of internalizing God's word, paralleling Ezekiel 2:8.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 2:5 indicates that the rebellious house may choose to forbear hearing the prophet's message.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:5 states that the people may either hear or forbear, showing their choice to reject or accept the prophetic message.

questions.question: In the historical context of Ezekiel 2, what does the description of Israel as 'impudent children and stiffhearted' reflect about their condition during the Babylonian exile?
options: Their persistent rebellion despite exile as a consequence of covenant unfaithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Their persistent rebellion despite exile as a consequence of covenant unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: The description in Ezekiel 2:4 reflects Israel's hardened resistance to repentance despite suffering exile as divine judgment.

questions.question: How does the theme of 'lamentations, mourning, and woe' in Ezekiel 2:10 foreshadow the tone of the book of Lamentations?
options: It anticipates the tragic consequences of Jerusalem’s fall
It contradicts the hopeful messages in Lamentations
It refers only to personal grief
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates the tragic consequences of Jerusalem’s fall
questions.explanation: The scroll's content in Ezekiel 2:10 foreshadows the sorrowful themes developed in Lamentations, which mourns Jerusalem’s destruction.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 2:3, to whom is Ezekiel sent, and how are they described?
options: To the children of Israel, a rebellious nation
To the Gentiles, a holy people
To the priests, a faithful group
To the kings of Israel, a wise nation
questions.correctAnswer: To the children of Israel, a rebellious nation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:3 states that God sends Ezekiel to the children of Israel, describing them as a rebellious nation that has transgressed against God. This theme of rebellion is echoed in Deuteronomy 9:7, Jeremiah 7:23-24, Romans 11:2-4, and Hebrews 3:8, emphasizing humanity's persistent rebellion against God.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 2:2, what enters into Ezekiel when God speaks to him?
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:2 describes the Spirit entering Ezekiel when God speaks to him, enabling him to stand and hear God's message. This highlights the Holy Spirit's role in empowering prophets, consistent with Isaiah 61:1, John 14:26, Acts 1:8, and 2 Timothy 3:16.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 2:6, what metaphors are used to describe the challenges Ezekiel will face among the rebellious house?
questions.correctAnswer: Briers, thorns, and scorpions
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:6 uses the imagery of briers, thorns, and scorpions to depict the hostile environment Ezekiel will endure among a rebellious people. This metaphor illustrates opposition to God's messengers, as also seen in Matthew 13:7, Luke 8:7, 2 Corinthians 12:7, and Revelation 2:10.

questions.question: What does God instruct Ezekiel to do with the words He gives him, regardless of how the people respond, according to Ezekiel 2:7?
options: Speak His words whether they will hear or forbear
Only speak if they are willing to listen
questions.correctAnswer: Speak His words whether they will hear or forbear
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:7 commands Ezekiel to speak God's words regardless of the people's response, emphasizing the prophet's duty to proclaim truth faithfully. This is consistent with Jeremiah 1:7-10, Amos 3:7, Acts 20:27, and 2 Timothy 4:2 about faithful proclamation despite opposition.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 2:4 characterize the children of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Impudent children and stiffhearted
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:4 describes Israel as impudent and stiffhearted, indicating their persistent rebellion and resistance to God's voice. This characterization aligns with Exodus 32:9, Jeremiah 6:10, Romans 2:5, and Hebrews 3:8 describing hard-heartedness.

questions.question: What is the significance of the roll of a book shown to Ezekiel in Ezekiel 2:9-10?
options: It contains lamentations, mourning, and woe
It contains laws for the priests
It contains a genealogy of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It contains lamentations, mourning, and woe
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:9-10 reveals that the scroll given to Ezekiel contains lamentations, mourning, and woe, signifying judgment and sorrow upon Israel. This reflects the prophetic message of judgment seen in Jeremiah 9:1, Lamentations 2:11, Amos 5:16, and Revelation 6:12-17.

questions.question: What does God command Ezekiel in Ezekiel 2:8 when He says, 'Eat that I give thee'?
questions.correctAnswer: Receive and internalize God's message
questions.explanation: In Ezekiel 2:8, God instructs Ezekiel to 'eat' the scroll, a metaphor for internalizing God's words so he can faithfully deliver the message. This is echoed in Jeremiah 15:16, Revelation 10:9-10, Deuteronomy 8:3, and John 6:51 where God's word is likened to sustenance.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 2:5, what will the people know despite their rebellion?
options: That there hath been a prophet among them
That they will be forgiven immediately
That they are chosen above all nations
questions.correctAnswer: That there hath been a prophet among them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:5 affirms that whether the people listen or not, they will know a prophet has been among them, demonstrating God's faithfulness to warn them. Similar affirmations are found in Amos 3:7, Jeremiah 1:10, Acts 7:52, and Hebrews 1:1-2.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 2:1, what is Ezekiel instructed to do before God speaks to him?
questions.correctAnswer: Stand upon his feet
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:1 instructs Ezekiel to stand upon his feet to receive God's message, symbolizing readiness and attentiveness. This posture of standing to receive divine revelation is also noted in Revelation 1:17, Acts 7:55, Psalm 119:105, and Isaiah 6:8.

questions.question: How does God describe the house of Israel in Ezekiel 2:6?
questions.correctAnswer: A rebellious house
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:6 calls Israel a rebellious house, emphasizing their persistent disobedience and resistance to God. This description is consistent with Exodus 32:9, Jeremiah 5:23, Romans 11:28, and Hebrews 3:12 describing spiritual rebellion.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'whether they will hear, or whether they will forbear' in Ezekiel 2:7 imply about Ezekiel's prophetic mission?
options: He must proclaim God's message regardless of response
He should only speak if they listen
He must alter the message for acceptance
questions.correctAnswer: He must proclaim God's message regardless of response
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:7 teaches that Ezekiel's duty is to faithfully deliver God's words regardless of people's acceptance, underscoring the prophetic obligation. This principle is evident in Jeremiah 1:17-19, Amos 3:8, Acts 20:27, and 2 Timothy 4:2.

questions.question: What attribute of God is revealed by His sending Ezekiel to a rebellious nation in Ezekiel 2:3?
options: God's preference for the righteous only
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice combined with mercy
questions.explanation: Sending Ezekiel to a rebellious nation (Ezekiel 2:3) reveals God's justice in confronting sin and His mercy in offering warning and opportunity for repentance. This is consistent with Exodus 34:6-7, Psalm 103:8, Romans 2:4, and 2 Peter 3:9.

questions.question: What warning does God give Ezekiel in Ezekiel 2:6 about his attitude toward the rebellious people?
options: Be not afraid of them nor their words
Only speak when they are respectful
questions.correctAnswer: Be not afraid of them nor their words
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:6 encourages Ezekiel not to fear the rebellious people's words or demeanor, highlighting God’s empowerment to withstand opposition. Similar exhortations appear in Isaiah 41:10, 2 Timothy 1:7, Joshua 1:9, and Psalm 27:1.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 2:10, what is unique about the writing on the scroll Ezekiel sees?
options: It is written within and without
It is written only on the front
It is written in an unknown language
It is written in gold letters
questions.correctAnswer: It is written within and without
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:10 notes the scroll is written on both the inside and outside, indicating the completeness and inescapability of the message of lamentation and judgment. This form of divine revelation is paralleled in Jeremiah 36:2, Revelation 5:1, Isaiah 29:11, and Habakkuk 2:2.

questions.question: What does God tell Ezekiel to avoid becoming like in Ezekiel 2:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellious like that rebellious house
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 2:8 commands Ezekiel not to be rebellious like the people to whom he is sent, emphasizing the prophet's obedience. This distinction between prophet's obedience and people's rebellion is seen in Jeremiah 1:17, 1 Kings 19:9-13, John 6:38, and Hebrews 5:8.
